entry.title: WebCodecs VideoFrame Metadata Registry ‚Äì rtpTimestamp field
entry.content:
Specification title

WebCodecs VideoFrame Metadata Registry ‚Äì rtpTimestamp field

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

ttps://www.w3.org/TR/webcodecs-video-frame-metadata-registry/#dom-videoframemetadata

Explainer URL (if available)

GoogleChrome/chromium-dashboard#5009

Proposal author(s)

No response

MDN URL

No response

Caniuse.com URL

No response

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

No response

WebKit standards-position

No response

Other information

  1. Please provide the title of the specification (or a suitable name for the proposal if no specification exists yet).

WebCodecs VideoFrame Metadata Registry ‚Äì rtpTimestamp field

  1. Please provide a short summary of the proposal.

This proposal exposes the rtpTimestamp field from WebRTC video frames via the JavaScript-facing VideoFrame.metadata() dictionary. This enables developers to correlate decoded video frames with their original RTP transport timestamps.

This is especially useful in applications using MediaStreamTrackProcessor or WebCodecs to build custom video processing pipelines. Exposing rtpTimestamp helps support:

  • Audio/video synchronization
  • End-to-end latency measurement
  • Debugging and performance analysis
  1. Please provide the names, affiliations, and GitHub usernames of anyone who may be able to provide additional context.
  • Anantanarayanan G Iyengar (Nvidia) ‚Äì @aiyengar
  • Dale Curtis (Google) ‚Äì @dalecurtis (if appropriate)

  1. Please link to any explainer or specification.
    Specification:
    https://www.w3.org/TR/webcodecs-video-frame-metadata-registry/#dom-videoframemetadata-rtptimestamp
    Explainer:
    GoogleChrome/chromium-dashboard#5009

  2. Please link to any primary Chromium bug entry, ChromeStatus.com entry, or equivalent.

  • ChromeStatus: https://chromestatus.com/feature/5186046555586560
  • Chromium bug: https://crbug.com/414545889
  • CL: https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/6499588
  1. Please describe the results you are hoping to see from this request.

We are requesting Mozilla‚Äôs position on exposing rtpTimestamp in VideoFrameMetadata. If there are any concerns with the approach, we‚Äôd appreciate feedback or alternative suggestions.

  1. Please provide the current state of implementation (e.g. in Chrome, Firefox, Safari).
  • Chrome: Implemented behind a runtime flag (VideoFrameMetadataRtpTimestamp)
  • Firefox: Not yet implemented
  • Safari: Not yet implemented
  1. Does this feature depend on any other work currently in progress?

No. It builds on existing WebRTC and WebCodecs infrastructure. The feature simply makes an existing native metadata field available to JavaScript when present.

entry.title: Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive scripts
entry.content:
Specification title

Cache sharing for extremely-pervasive scripts

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

https://chromestatus.com/feature/5202380930678784

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

@pmeenan

MDN URL

No response

Caniuse.com URL

No response

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

@zcorpan @Lars @mt

WebKit standards-position

No response

Other information

Adding an issue on behalf of Google for https://chromestatus.com/feature/5202380930678784 -- They have Firefox/Safari marked as N/A for s-p, but I think this is important to consider the impacts on the web and users from this proposal. Officially this is just an internal implementation detail in Chrome that impacts security and privacy of Chrome users, but there are indirect impacts on the Web itself.

The biggest concern I have is the entrenchment of incumbents/large-tech-companies, by giving their resources a performance advantage over any possible competitors, either now or in the future. This gives a bias towards centralization. Even if it were made adaptive in some manner, it would still have the effect of extending the advantages enjoyed by large tech companies over competitors.

I suggest a negative position.

entry.title: Send Sec-Purpose header for link type prefetch (rel=prefetch)
entry.content:
Specification title

Send Sec-Purpose header for link type prefetch (rel=prefetch)

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

whatwg/html#11294

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

@srwei

MDN URL

No response

Caniuse.com URL

No response

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

No response

WebKit standards-position

No response

Other information

Firefox has sent ‚ÄòX-moz: prefetch‚Äô.

Chrome currently passes both 'Purpose: prefetch' and 'Sec-Purpose: prefetch' headers as part of prefetch through speculation rules. However, only 'Purpose: prefetch' is passed with link rel=prefetch. It would be nice to standardize this header for both speculation rules and by adding 'Sec-Purpose: prefetch' header to the latter.

Each browser uses non-standardized header name that is not aligned with CORS spec. This change will introduce better interoperability and compatibility for a long term.

chromestatus: https://chromestatus.com/feature/6247959677108224

entry.title: [css-variables-1] Short-circuiting var(), attr(), env()
entry.content:
Specification title

css-variables-1

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

https://drafts.csswg.org/css-variables/#replace-a-var-function

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

@andruud

MDN URL

No response

Caniuse.com URL

No response

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

No response

WebKit standards-position

WebKit/standards-positions#489

Other information

In w3c/csswg-drafts#11500, the CSSWG resolved to make all substitution functions short-circuiting, meaning that we don't evaluate branches we don't care about (not even to look for cycles). In the issue, we were not sure if we could actually apply this resolution to var() due to certain tricks that rely on the existing behavior. However, my compat investigation did not find any evidence of this trick being in widespread use, and I consider this a safe change to make.

entry.title: Updating QuotaExceededError to a DOMException derived interface
entry.content:
Specification title

QuotaExceededError

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

whatwg/webidl#1465

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

@domenic

MDN URL

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/DOMException#quotaexceedederror

Caniuse.com URL

https://caniuse.com/mdn-api_domexception

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

@smaug----

WebKit standards-position

WebKit/standards-positions#468

Other information

Description
Currently, when the web platform wants to tell you when you've exceeded quota, it will use DOMException with the specific name property set to QuotaExceededError. However this does not allow carrying additional information.

This proposes removing "QuotaExceededError" from the list of built-in DOMException names, and instead creates a class name QuotaExceededError from the list of built-in DOMException and has the additional optional properties quota and requested. We propose all instances of specs that throw "QuotaExceededError" DOMExceptions get upgraded to instead throw QuotaExceededErrors. For now, such specs would leave the quota and requested properties at their default value of null, but they could eventually upgrade to include that data, if it's useful for their use case (and isn't, e.g., a privacy leak).

The proposal PR outlines scenarios where this change may not be backward-incompatible. However, think they are rare coding patterns and anticipate low interoperability risk.

Previous discussions
Previously brought up in a WHATNOT (2025-02-06) with some subtle positive signals of interest while raising compat concerns.

entry.title: Ignore Letter Spacing in Cursive Scripts
entry.content:
Specification title

Ignore Letter Spacing in Cursive Scripts

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

https://www.w3.org/TR/css-text-3/#cursive-tracking

Explainer URL (if available)

No response

Proposal author(s)

seanand-dev

MDN URL

No response

Caniuse.com URL

No response

Bugzilla URL

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1342835

Mozillians who can provide input

No response

WebKit standards-position

No response

Other information

This feature adds logic to ignore the letter-spacing setting for cursive scripts as specified by the web author, in line with the spec, to ensure that letter spacing does not disrupt word structure and aims to produce better user experience for users relying on cursive scripts.

The spec suggests that the UA may apply letter spacing to cursive scripts by translating the total extra space into cursive elongation or compression. Otherwise, if the UA cannot expand text from a cursive script without breaking its cursive connections, it must not apply spacing between any pair of that script‚Äôs typographic letter units at all.

Ignoring letter spacing altogether for cursive scripts is simpler and helps avoid performance issues as handling spacing for such scripts requires complex calculations to maintain cursive connections and account for script-specific factors like elongation glyphs, typefaces, and calligraphy preferences. With this feature, Chromium ensures that cursive scripts will be readable and properly spaced, even if the fonts don‚Äôt have advanced typographic features.

The scripts that we are proposing to apply this to in Chromium are Arabic, Hanifi Rohingya, Mandaic, Mongolian, N‚ÄôKo, Phags Pa, and Syriac as these scripts are considered cursive as per spec.

entry.title: Meta: gh-data.py script errors on querying GitHub API for repository issues starting with page 11
entry.content:
The gh-data.py script seems to not work provided the underlying repository that's being queried has more than 10 pages of results. This probably only applies for local execution without authentication as the script seems to work for pages beyond 10 in CI.

  • Page 10: https://api.github.com/repos/mozilla/standards-positions/issues?direction=asc&state=all&per_page=100&page=10 ‚Üí normal set of results
  • Page 11: https://api.github.com/repos/mozilla/standards-positions/issues?direction=asc&state=all&per_page=100&page=11 ‚Üí error response with status 422 and error message API rate limit exceeded for 93.193.43.106. (But here's the good news: Authenticated requests get a higher rate limit. Check out the documentation for more details.)

I got this error on page 11 the first time I ran the gh-data.py script locally so I feel fairly confident this is a legitimate problem. I consistently get the error above starting on page 11.

To fix this, the script should probably use cursor-based pagination (see https://docs.github.com/en/rest/using-the-rest-api/using-pagination-in-the-rest-api?apiVersion=2022-11-28#using-link-headers).

I'm happy to file a PR to fix this if you like (though I need a little while to test my homework as I'm now rate-limited üòÅ).

(As an aside, I also can't run merge-data.py locally because the ruamel.yaml package crashes on parsing a ‚Äù character (though it has no trouble parsing ‚Äú, ‚Äò, or ‚Äô) in the activities.yml file. Removing it, and the script works. A fix local to this project could be to programmatically replace ‚Äú with ‚Äò and ‚Äù with ‚Äô before passing yml_file to yaml.load.)

entry.title: Web Neural Network API
entry.content:
Specification title

Web Neural Network API

Specification or proposal URL (if available)

https://www.w3.org/TR/webnn/

Explainer URL (if available)

https://github.com/webmachinelearning/webnn/blob/main/explainer.md

Proposal author(s)

@huningxin

MDN URL

there isn't one

Caniuse.com URL

https://caniuse.com/?search=WebNN

Bugzilla URL

No response

Mozillians who can provide input

No response

WebKit standards-position

there isn't one yet

Other information

WebKit does not have a position, but does have an issue now.

The Spec for Web Neural Networks is highly active in the W3C activity dashboard.

It proposes a navigator.ml that will allow users to write neural networks, currently only for inference, that will be delegated to a "native" OS ML framework: DirectML, CoreML, OPENVINO, NN Android (unmaintained).

Some questions that seem relevant to me are:

  1. Are there privacy issues?
  2. Can models be inspected or are they allowed to be obfuscated?
  3. What do they mean by "native", and wouldn't this lock out other participants?
  4. How much effort will be on the browsers side? (seems a lot to me.)
  5. Why not to propose just the use of GPUs with WebGPU which would be a single, portable codebase even though it sacrifices NPU support and some speed? (their answer in comments and explainer-section is that WebGPU wouldn't help to use the NPUs/DSPs.)

Some of those questions are also in the WebNN Github Repo.

In a single image, this is what they propose (copied from their repository):
